Description: Fragmentary limestone figure of a standing male, the upper body, legs and base now missing. The preserved section shows the waist and thighs of the striding male figure, with the outline of the shendyt kilt visible around the lower portion of the fragment. There are traces of red and black paint across the lower stone surface area, and modern markings in pencil, black and red ink at the top of the fragment on the reverse. There are some chips to the stone surface across the lower broken edge and small abrasions to the mid-section.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis), Stratum AΠ4 ('bothros' / 'trench with bowls')
Curator's comments: The fragment is recorded as being discovered within the sanctuary of Apollo area of Naukratis, where other figures were found by Petrie during his excavation of the site that are also now in the British Museum collection (including: EA 68823 (1886,0401.1489), EA 68824 (1886,0401.1491) and EA 68825 (1886,0401.1492)). Due to the fragmentary nature of the object, it’s not possible to determine the original identity of the figure. General Sources: W.M.F. Petrie, 1886. Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CD.016)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Committee of)
